            TRUST FUND,TF020350-DANISH CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated as
            satisfactory with project outcome likely. Both World Bank
            and Borrower performance were generally satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned include: Traditional systems of woodland
            management are strengthened by working with villagers to
            protect and conserve these resources themselves and through
            socio-legal mechanisms which villagers themselves control
            and maintain. Community involvement in joint forest
            management of government reserves can lead to improving the
            condition of reserves; pilot approaches could be
            strengthened by transferring decisionmaking more fully to
            the communities involved. Dry woodland management poses good
            opportunities because of the resilience of the woodland to
            harvesting, the cost-effectiveness of relying on natural
            regeneration with minimal silvicultural treatments, and the
            few risks to the environment posed by sustainable management
            of dry woodland ecosystems. Adopting the farmers'
            simple technologies is more apt than relying on high-tech
            approaches. Community participation in surveying village
            lands is essential and cost-effective since it reduced
            litigation, leading to considerable savings in time and
            resources. When project identification and preparation is
            bolstered by strategic studies, action-oriented research,
            and ESW, there are significant benefits. Future investments
            will likely be jeopardized without institutional reform.
            Technical supervision of advisory services needs to be
            strengthened and supported.
